private_information: I hold disks A,B,C,D,E,F from top to bottom where A is smallest and F is largest
left_peg.goal: All disks A,B,C,D,E,F must be moved to the right peg preserving size ordering

middle_peg.goal: All disks A,B,C,D,E,F must be moved to the right peg preserving size ordering

right_peg.goal: All disks A,B,C,D,E,F must be moved to the right peg preserving size ordering

orchestrator.goal: All disks A,B,C,D,E,F must be moved to the right peg preserving size ordering

public_information: Three pegs named left middle and right are available
Six disks labeled A B C D E F exist where A is smallest and F is largest
Only one disk may be moved at a time
A larger disk may never be placed on top of a smaller disk
Initial configuration: left peg top to bottom A B C D E F, middle peg empty, right peg empty
Goal configuration: right peg top to bottom A B C D E F, left and middle pegs empty

describe.system_prompt: You represent the left peg in a Tower of Hanoi instance. Describe precisely your local state and constraints without producing PDDL. Provide which disks you currently hold in order from top to bottom, which disks you can accept on top of you and any placement constraints that follow from the rule forbidding larger on smaller. Keep the description concise and structured.
describe.prompt: Your name is left_peg. You have access to the following public information: Three pegs left middle right, six disks A B C D E F, move rules and the initial and goal configurations. You have the following private information: I hold disks A B C D E F top to bottom. Describe your local state and acceptance constraints in a concise structured form. Do not emit PDDL.

describe.system_prompt: You represent the middle peg in a Tower of Hanoi instance. Describe precisely your local state and constraints without producing PDDL. Provide which disks you currently hold in order from top to bottom and which disks you can accept on top of you. Keep the description concise and structured.
describe.prompt: Your name is middle_peg. You have access to the public information about the pegs and the disks and the move rules. You have the following private information: I hold no disks initially. Describe your local state and acceptance constraints in a concise structured form. Do not emit PDDL.

describe.system_prompt: You represent the right peg in a Tower of Hanoi instance. Describe precisely your local state and constraints without producing PDDL. Provide which disks you currently hold in order from top to bottom and which disks you can accept on top of you. Keep the description concise and structured.
describe.prompt: Your name is right_peg. You have access to the public information about the pegs and the disks and the move rules. You have the following private information: I hold no disks initially. Describe your local state and acceptance constraints in a concise structured form. Do not emit PDDL.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an orchestrator that must produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem suitable for the FastDownwards planner to solve the Tower of Hanoi instance with six disks and three pegs. Produce a STRIPS-compatible PDDL domain and a PDDL problem. Use clear predicate and action names. Include a predicate that represents disk on peg and disk on disk if useful. Enforce the rule that a larger disk cannot be placed on a smaller one. The domain and problem must reflect the initial configuration and the goal configuration. Enclose the domain between <domain></domain> tags and the problem between <problem></problem> tags. Do not assume additional hidden facts beyond the provided descriptions. Keep actions and predicate names unambiguous and consistent. Target FastDownwards solver compatibility.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. You receive structured local descriptions from the three peg agents describing their current stacks and acceptance constraints. Integrate that information with the public environment rules to produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem for the FastDownwards planner that achieves the global goal: move all disks A B C D E F from left peg to right peg preserving the size ordering. Keep representation clear and unambiguous. Enclose the domain between <domain></domain> tags and the problem between <problem></problem> tags.
